definitions: able to speak, write, or understand several different languages fluently
presented or available in more than one language for accessibility
examples: The multilingual teacher could communicate with all her students
Many international companies prefer multilingual employees for global teams
The museum offers multilingual audio guides for tourists
This multilingual website automatically detects your browser language

definitions: describing a company or organization that operates in several different countries
involving or consisting of people or things from many different nations
examples: The multinational corporation has offices in fifty countries
She works for a multinational technology firm based in Silicon Valley
The multinational peacekeeping force included soldiers from twelve countries
They organized a multinational conference on climate change

definitions: having been increased by a mathematical multiplication process
having grown or increased greatly in number or amount
examples: The multiplied result gave us a total of 240
Their multiplied efforts produced faster results than expected
The multiplied problems became too difficult to manage alone
Her multiplied responsibilities required better time management skills

definitions: designed or suitable for several different uses or functions
examples: This multipurpose tool can cut, drill, and sand materials
The school built a multipurpose hall for sports and assemblies

definitions: consisting of or involving people of many different races
having ancestors from two or more different racial backgrounds
examples: The multiracial community celebrated its diversity with annual festivals
They formed a multiracial coalition to address social issues
Her multiracial background gave her unique perspectives on identity
The multiracial family embraced traditions from all their cultures

definitions: saying nothing or refusing to speak about something
examples: She stayed mum about the surprise party plans
The witness remained mum during the police questioning

definitions: lacking interest or excitement; routine and often boring
concerned with the ordinary world rather than spiritual matters
examples: She grew tired of her mundane office job
Even mundane tasks like washing dishes can be meditative
The monk left behind mundane concerns to focus on enlightenment
They discussed mundane matters before addressing deeper issues

definitions: relating to a town or city and its local government
examples: The municipal elections will determine the new city council
They pay municipal taxes to fund local services

definitions: relating to or resembling a large painting on a wall
examples: The mural artist transformed the blank building wall
They commissioned a mural design for the school cafeteria

definitions: having been killed unlawfully and with premeditation
examples: The murdered victim was found in the abandoned warehouse
Police investigated the case of the murdered businessman

definitions: having the intent or capability to murder; extremely violent or cruel
extremely arduous, difficult, or unpleasant in a way that exhausts
examples: The detective tracked down the murderous criminal
She saw murderous rage flash in his eyes
The murderous heat made outdoor work nearly impossible
They faced a murderous climb up the steep mountain

definitions: dark and gloomy, especially due to thick mist or unclear water
not fully explained or understood; questionable or suspicious
examples: The murky water made it impossible to see the bottom
They walked carefully through the murky fog
The company's murky financial dealings attracted investigation
His murky past made voters question his candidacy

definitions: having well-developed muscles; strong and physically powerful
characterized by strength, power, or forcefulness in style or approach
examples: The muscular athlete easily lifted the heavy weights
Years of swimming gave her a muscular physique
The president delivered a muscular defense of the policy
The company needs a more muscular marketing strategy

definitions: characterized by deep thought or careful consideration
examples: She had a musing expression while considering the proposal
His musing tone suggested he was still thinking

definitions: capable of or subject to change or alteration in form, nature, or substance
examples: Human opinions are mutable and influenced by experience
The mutable nature of fashion means trends constantly evolve

definitions: resulting from or showing the effect of genetic mutation
examples: Scientists studied the mutant gene that caused the disease
The mutant plants showed resistance to common pesticides

definitions: unable to speak due to physical or medical reasons
refraining from speech or temporarily speechless; subdued or softened
examples: The mute child communicated through sign language
Birth complications left him permanently mute
She stood mute with shock at the news
The mute colors created a calming atmosphere

definitions: having a softened, subdued, or less bright quality in color or sound
expressed in a restrained, subtle, or understated way
examples: The room featured muted earth tones and soft lighting
The muted sound of traffic came through closed windows
Critics offered muted praise for the controversial film
Her muted response suggested disagreement without confrontation

definitions: having been violently injured, disfigured, or damaged by cutting or tearing
examples: The mutilated manuscript was barely readable after the fire
Archaeologists found mutilated statues in the ancient ruins

definitions: refusing to obey orders or showing open rebellion against authority
examples: The mutinous crew refused to follow the captain's orders
She shot him a mutinous glare before leaving

definitions: countless or extremely great in number; having innumerable aspects or elements
examples: The night sky displayed myriad stars twinkling above
She faced myriad challenges in starting her business

definitions: relating to mysticism or having spiritual significance beyond ordinary understanding
examples: The mystic symbols carved in stone puzzled archaeologists
She felt a mystic connection to the ancient place

definitions: relating to mystics or religious mysticism; having spiritual meaning or reality
inspiring a sense of spiritual mystery, awe, and fascination
examples: The mystical teachings emphasized direct experience of the divine
Many cultures have mystical traditions passed down through generations
The forest had a mystical quality in the morning mist
She described her mystical experience during meditation

definitions: relating to or found in myths and mythology
having qualities of legendary importance or heroic scale
examples: The mythic gods of ancient Greece influenced Western culture
Scholars study mythic narratives across different civilizations
His mythic status in jazz grew after his death
The team's mythic comeback will be remembered for generations

definitions: occurring in or characteristic of myths or folk tales
existing only in imagination; fictitious or not based in reality
examples: Dragons and unicorns are mythical creatures from folklore
The story featured mythical heroes on epic quests
The perfect work-life balance seems almost mythical these days
His mythical fortune turned out to be greatly exaggerated

definitions: relating to, based on, or appearing in myths or mythology
examples: The museum displayed mythological artifacts from ancient civilizations
She studied mythological stories from around the world

definitions: persistently harassing, criticizing, or finding fault in an irritating way
persistently painful or worrying in a way that won't go away
examples: His nagging complaints about the food annoyed everyone
She couldn't concentrate due to her mother's nagging reminders
The nagging pain in his shoulder kept him awake
A nagging doubt about the decision troubled her mind

definitions: showing lack of experience, wisdom, or judgment; innocent and unsuspecting
examples: Her naive trust in strangers sometimes worried her friends
It would be naive to think this problem will solve itself

definitions: having no name or with name unknown or withheld
too unpleasant or disturbing to describe or mention
examples: The nameless donor gave millions to the hospital
Many nameless soldiers died in the forgotten battle
She felt a nameless dread creeping over her
The victims suffered nameless horrors during the war

definitions: relating to the act of giving names or identifying something
examples: The naming ceremony for the baby was held Sunday
Company naming conventions help organize computer files systematically

definitions: having hair with a tightly curled or kinked texture
having a fuzzy, downy, or soft raised texture
examples: She proudly wore her nappy hair in its natural state
The salon specialized in caring for nappy hair textures
The nappy fabric felt soft against the baby's skin
This nappy wool makes excellent winter sweaters

definitions: having an excessive interest in or admiration of oneself and one's appearance or achievements
examples: His narcissistic behavior alienated his friends and colleagues
The narcissistic leader only cared about personal glory

definitions: relating to or designating drugs that relieve pain and induce sleep
inducing drowsiness, sleep, or stupor; having a soothing effect
examples: The doctor prescribed narcotic painkillers after the surgery
Police found narcotic substances during the raid
The professor's narcotic voice made students fall asleep
The narcotic effect of the warm bath relaxed her

definitions: having been made less wide or having less space between sides
having been reduced in range, extent, or scope
examples: Her narrowed eyes showed suspicion about his story
The narrowed road could only fit one car
The narrowed focus helped them complete the project faster
Their narrowed options left little room for negotiation

definitions: becoming less wide or more restricted in width, scope, or range
examples: The narrowing gap between them made passing difficult
Doctors monitored the narrowing arteries with concern

definitions: relating to the nose or the nasal cavity
spoken or sounding as if produced through the nose
examples: She used nasal spray to relieve her congestion
The doctor examined his nasal passages for blockages
His nasal voice was distinctive and easily recognized
The singer's nasal tone didn't appeal to everyone

definitions: just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential; emerging
examples: The nascent technology showed promise for medical applications
Her nascent interest in art blossomed into a career

definitions: relating to the place or time of one's birth
examples: She returned to her natal village after many years
The natal chart showed planetary positions at birth

definitions: relating to or supporting the interests and culture of one's nation, often to the exclusion of others
examples: The nationalist movement sought independence from colonial rule
His nationalist speeches appealed to patriotic voters

definitions: characterized by strong patriotic feelings, especially belief in the superiority of one's own country
examples: The nationalistic fervor grew stronger during the international crisis
Critics warned against nationalistic policies that could harm trade

definitions: extending or occurring throughout an entire nation or country
examples: The company launched a nationwide advertising campaign
The nationwide strike affected millions of workers

definitions: relating to policies favoring native inhabitants over immigrants
examples: The nativist policies restricted immigration from certain countries
His nativist rhetoric appealed to voters' economic fears

definitions: smart and fashionable in dress or appearance; dapper
examples: He always wore natty suits to business meetings
Her natty appearance impressed the interview panel

definitions: having been admitted to citizenship of a country (British spelling)
introduced from another region and now reproducing naturally in the wild
examples: The naturalised citizens voted for the first time
She became a naturalised British citizen last year
These naturalised plants now grow wild throughout the region
The naturalised species threatened native wildlife

definitions: representing things in a way that is accurate and true to life
based on the theory that everything arises from natural causes
examples: The naturalistic acting made the film feel like a documentary
Her naturalistic paintings captured every detail perfectly
Scientists took a naturalistic approach to studying animal behavior
The naturalistic philosophy rejected supernatural explanations

definitions: having been admitted to citizenship of a country (American spelling)
introduced from another region and now reproducing naturally in the wild
examples: The naturalized Americans celebrated their citizenship ceremony
His naturalized status allowed him to vote
The naturalized flowers spread throughout the meadow
Botanists studied how species became naturalized

definitions: behaving badly or not being obedient; mischievous
mildly rude or indecent, typically in a playful way
examples: The naughty children refused to go to bed
Santa's list showed who was naughty or nice
She gave him a naughty wink across the room
The comedian's naughty jokes made some people blush

definitions: relating to sailors, ships, or navigation on water
examples: The room featured nautical decorations like anchors and ropes
He studied nautical charts before the sailing trip

definitions: relating to a country's navy or warships
examples: The naval base housed dozens of military vessels
She joined the naval academy straight from high school

definitions: wide and deep enough for ships or boats to travel through
able to be steered, directed, or managed through
examples: The navigable river allowed trade between inland cities
Only small boats could use the barely navigable channel
The website's navigable interface made finding information easy
She found the complex regulations barely navigable
